text:
I have heard a lot of conflicting views about whether or not to position yourself as an x for y brand(eg uber for corporates).

I, for one, feel when explaining a business model, these references come in handy and there shouldn’t be anything wrong with it. If the market is already well acquainted with one business, why not use it to explain yours. What are your thoughts though?

elements.text:

text:
I have used such positioning in the past and it has served me well. I don’t see any problem with it as long as it serves a purpose. Don’t do it for the heck of it because then it reads/sounds annoying.

For example: “Make your post-purchase experience as seamless as Amazon”

elements.text:
I have used such positioning in the past and it has served me well. I don’t see any problem with it as long as it serves a purpose. Don’t do it for the heck of it because then it reads/sounds annoying.

For example: “Make your post-purchase experience as seamless as Amazon”

text:
I used it extensively at typito. Few of our early adopters told us we were like canva for video. We milked the heck out of it after that. Used it in Landing pages, pitch decks and all. Helped a ton with seo as people wanted something like canva but for video then. 

Looking back, one drawback is that it is depending on that bigger brand not coming into your territory. As canva started creating its own video editing tool it was getting challenging to differentiate and we invited lot of pricing comparisons etc. Canva is free for basic why do you cost so high for even basic plan etc. So tread with caution and build a long term branding positioning strategy but you can definitely leverage Uber for x kind of positioning when you are early on in journey, need to ride a wave or such. Don't think it's healthy in long run

text: And investors love such pitches in my observations. I have heard interviews where independent film makers/directors also say a movie/series is like it's Narcos but for sand mining or such

text: Thanks for the insight <@U02VA7QD8UB> and <@U031QKGPNRK>, I agree with both of you. In fact, Tej, I think the same concern crossed my mind as well. But then I feel at least in the shorter term, it makes adoption easier
